sense.name: saloon, establishment primarily serving alcohol
sense.examples: The bars all close in this town at 1 am. John and Mary explored various wine bars in Venice. She had dropped out of school and become a bar fly. (hangs out in bars) Mike and Pete went to a topless bar last night. Mary and Sally spent the evening in Madrid exploring tapas bars. (focus is on wine)

sense.name: a counter or area where food or drink are provided
sense.examples: This restaurant has a nice salad bar. The reception had hot hors d'oeuvres and a cash bar. (drink counter where you pay for drinks) John installed a wet bar in his finished basement. (drink area with a sink) I bought a bag of pretzels at the hospital's snack bar. Have you tried the sushi bar at that new restaurant?

sense.name: any rigid rod, usually metal or wood
sense.examples: That neighborhood has a lot of bars on the windows. The man packed tobacco into his pipe with a tamping bar. They were finally able to open the jammed cellar door with a pry bar. These brass towel bars are quite expensive. This quilting machine has three racks and six fabric bars.

sense.name: a symbol of musical notation that demarcates sets of notes
sense.examples: There are six bars of introduction before the singer's entrance. (six measures of music) The end of this movement of the symphony is indicated with double bars. It's a twelve bar blues progression.

sense.name: sports apparatus serving as an obstacle
sense.examples: The football hit the bar between the goal posts and bounced back. The bars on the jumps in Olympic equestrian events are set above six feet. Their new microprocessor has raised the bar for performance yet again. (figurative)

sense.name: a state of hindrance or prohibition to something
sense.examples: There is a bar against cameras in that courtroom. He believes society still maintains a color bar between the races. The boy's dyslexia proved to be no bar in getting into a good college. Don't let feelings of insecurity be the bar to your success.

sense.name: a unit of atmospheric pressure
sense.examples: The barometer has fallen several bars in the last hour. The divers checked their pressure gauges to see how many bars were remaining in their tanks.

sense.name: a ridge of sand usually submerged in a river or the sea
sense.examples: The keel of the boat got snagged on a sand bar. These sand bars are totally submerged at high tide.

sense.name: the legal profession
sense.examples: Bill just passed the bar exam. Her father is a member of the New York bar. He'll face the bar of public opinion. (figurative)

sense.name: a unit of a substance, formed in a block
sense.examples: How much does a bar of gold weight? He ate two whole bars of chocolate for lunch! The restrooms use liquid soap dispensers in place of bars of soap. Mary doesn't like granola bars.

sense.name: supporting apparatus used in gymnastics
sense.examples: The gymnast worked out on the high bar. She did a perfect dismount from the horizontal bar.

sense.name: a heating element
sense.examples: This space heater's heating element has three bars.

sense.name: a low rail in a courtroom or legislative hall
sense.examples: The prisoner stood at the bar gazing defiantly out at the courtroom. The people seated in the courtroom are not allowed to go past the bar.

sense.name: a narrow decorative stripe or band, used as insignia
sense.examples: Johnny's mother sewed the bars onto the sleeve of his Cub Scout uniform. Their family heraldic insignia has a blue bar at the top. The military brass all wore a lot of bars on their shoulders.

sense.name: a legal plea to remove an action in a court case
sense.examples: They think the prosecution will make a bar to dismiss that body of evidence.

sense.name: an elongated key on a keyboard or typewriter
sense.examples: Hit the space bar a few times. The space bar is the largest key on the keyboard.
